etymologies: early 17th century. Originally from classical Latin religātiōn-, religātiō action of tying up or making fast from religāt-, past participial stem of religāre + -iō

definitions: The action of binding together again (literal and figurative); the fact of being bound or constrained.

notes.text: Chiefly in religious contexts, with reference to the etymology of "religion".

definitions: The action of ligating a blood vessel or other structure for a second or further time; an instance of this.
The action of religating fragments of a nucleic acid molecule; an instance of this.
